worklogs.comment:
BryanCutler opened a new pull request #2190: ARROW-2743: [Java] Change CI script to remove project artifacts before building
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2190
 
 
   This adds a command to the Java CI script to remove project artifacts, of the current version, from the local Maven repo prior to building.  This is to catch a potential issue where the build might use parent poms from the local repo instead of in the current project. 
   
   The history of this issue is ARROW-1780 added a child pom 2 levels deep that used the arrow-java-root as parent but did not specify the parent path.  The build was able to pass because it found the parent pom in the local repo, but should have been using the one from the project.  Bug ARROW-2727 was reported because when trying a clean build without the parent pom in the repo, the build will fail.  This was resolved by specifying the correct parent relative path.

----------------------------------------------------------------

BryanCutler commented on issue #2190: ARROW-2743: [Java] Change CI script to remove project artifacts before building
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2190#issuecomment-401171767
 
 
   I could not get CI to fail.  From what I can tell, the issue does not happen with a newer version of maven.  It must be able to locate the parent POM some other way, and it is not installed in the local repo.
   
   I verified this locally by removing the parent POM relative path and running the cmd:
   `mvn -B install build-helper:remove-project-artifact -Dbuildhelper.failOnError=false`
   
   With mvn 3.3.9, I get the error saying it can not find the arrow-java-root POM, but with mvn 3.5.2 (the version used by CI) it is able find it and completes without error. I'm not sure there is anything we can do to catch a problem like this in the future except move to a lower version of mvn, what are your thoughts @wesm ?

wesm commented on issue #2190: ARROW-2743: [Java] Change CI script to remove project artifacts before building
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2190#issuecomment-401323245
 
 
   I think it's OK to merge a fix even if we can't trigger the failure in Travis CI (since it seems it's relying on some kind of caching behavior anyway).
   
   Can the same effect be reaped by deleting a particular directory under `$HOME/.m2`?

BryanCutler commented on issue #2190: ARROW-2743: [Java] Change CI script to remove project artifacts before building
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2190#issuecomment-401441888
 
 
   @wesm from what I can tell, Travis doesn't have anything cached in the local maven repo under `/home/travis/.m2/repository`, so this fix here would do nothing.  I think something changed in the newer versions of Maven so that it can find the parent pom within the same project without needing a relative path.  I can't find any documentation on this, but I'm able to see this behavior locally with Maven 3.5.2.  I'm going to close this since this change doesn't work and I'm out of ideas for now.

BryanCutler closed pull request #2190: ARROW-2743: [Java] Change CI script to remove project artifacts before building
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2190
 
 
   

This is a PR merged from a forked repository.
As GitHub hides the original diff on merge, it is displayed below for
the sake of provenance:

As this is a foreign pull request (from a fork), the diff is supplied
below (as it won't show otherwise due to GitHub magic):

diff --git a/ci/travis_script_java.sh b/ci/travis_script_java.sh
index a8ad94c5e8..fe7bfa31b1 100755
--- a/ci/travis_script_java.sh
+++ b/ci/travis_script_java.sh
@@ -23,7 +23,11 @@ JAVA_DIR=${TRAVIS_BUILD_DIR}/java
 
 pushd $JAVA_DIR
 
+echo "finding all in repo"
+find /home/travis/.m2/repository/
+echo "done"
+
 export MAVEN_OPTS="$MAVEN_OPTS -Dorg.slf4j.simpleLogger.defaultLogLevel=warn"
-mvn -B install
+mvn -B install build-helper:remove-project-artifact -Dbuildhelper.failOnError=false
 
 popd

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description: This bug was introduced in ARROW-1780. It is unclear why the bug was not triggered in Travis CI; we should see about fixing that
fields.summary: [Java] Travis CI test scripts did not catch POM file bug fixed in ARROW-2727

comments.body: My guess is that the local Maven repo had the java-root pom installed.  When the mvn build is running (by default) it will first search the next directory up, followed by the local repo.  If it is in the repo, then it won't cause a problem.  ARROW-2727 changes the default search path for the parent to the correct location, so I'm not sure if there is much to do in Travis except clean the local repo before build.
That is odd. Maybe Travis CI is caching something. We could add a {{git clean -fdx .}} in the Java script to see
Or sounds like we'd need to scrub the local Maven repo. Either way there's some state that's hiding build system issues

[~wesmckinn], would you be able to verify if the Travis CI has the following file: {{$HOME/.m2/repository/org/apache/arrow/arrow-java-root/0.10.0-SNAPSHOT/arrow-java-root-0.10.0-SNAPSHOT.pom}}?  If it does then that was most likely why problem didn't surface and I can submit a patch to clean it before each install.

I'm not sure how to check that. I guess we could, as a preventive measure, {{rm -rf $HOME/.m2/repository/org/apache/arrow}}. We should revert the fix in ARROW-2727 to make sure we get a failing build, then

Update - I was unable to make a possible fix for this in Travis CI and the only way I could think of to get Travis to catch an error like this is by downgrading Maven to 3.3.9 or similar, which I would not recommend. So I'm stopping work on this for now.
Thanks [~bryanc] for looking into it. I'll remove from the 0.10.0 milestone and we can revisit when/if it becomes an issue in the future
Closing for now until the issue recurs
